oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1925 Letter from John Trotwood Moore to Seth K. Martin
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Correspondence
Moore, John Trotwood, 1858-1929; Evolution; Evolution and anti-evolution; Creationism; Evolution (Biology) - Study and teaching - Law and legislation; Evolution - Religious aspects
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This two-sided, typed letter written by John Trotwood Moore to Seth K. Martin, an old Maury County friend living in Oakland, California, contains comments from Moore concerning the debate on evolutionary theory raging in Tennessee; on the eve of the John T. Scopes Trial.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Moore, John Trotwood, 1858-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Trotwood Moore had a high-profile at the time this letter was written. He was not only a well-known man of letters, but at this time, he was serving as the Tennessee State Librarian and Archivist, a position he held from 1919; until his death in 1929. This letter does highlight the national interest that was focused on Tennessee and the evolution debate following the passage of the Butler Bill and leading up to the Scopes Trial.
